    Undertsanding our 3D world

    Figure 1

    Image 1 of 1: ‘wireframe image room’

    Figure 2

    Image 1 of 1: ‘© REDPIXEL from AdobeStock’

    An additional challenge is that things in our space are constantly moving, and being subject to the laws of physics.

    Technologies for sensing

    Figure 1

    Image 1 of 1: ‘sensors’

    Figure 2

    Image 1 of 1: ‘motion sensor’

    Figure 3

    Image 1 of 1: ‘Ranex Smartwares 6000.293 © Raimond Spekking’

    Figure 4

    Image 1 of 1: ‘3d model’

    However, remember a polygonal meshes are RIGID. They do not move, unless they undertake a process to animated them.

    Image 1 of 1: ‘motion’

    Image 1 of 1: ‘icon’

    Also known as photogrammetry.

    Creating 3D models via SfM

    Figure 1

    Image 1 of 1: ‘Depth-of-field’

    Figure 2

    Image 1 of 1: ‘Best practice to photograph facades. DO NOT take a panorama image of a facade. DO walk along the facade taking overlapping pictures.’

    Figure 3

    Image 1 of 1: ‘Best practice to photograph rooms or closed spaces. DO NOT take various panorama images of the room. DO walk around the room taking overlapping pictures.’

    Figure 4

    Image 1 of 1: ‘Best practice to photograph objects. DO NOT take pictures without overlap. DO walk around the object taking overlapping pictures.’

    Figure 5

    Image 1 of 1: ‘12 cm Marker under wooden horse object’

    Figure 6

    Image 1 of 1: ‘Shadows created by the sunlight on Saint Viktor of Xanten Church, Dülmen, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany, Public domain, Dietmar Rabich , under CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons’

    Figure 7

    Image 1 of 1: ‘Overcast lighting on Statue of Queen Victoria, Brighton’

    Figure 8

    Image 1 of 1: ‘Static camera / move object’
